objects.author: Nick Bohr
objects.title: Coronavirus outbreak threatens to shut down UW-Madison campus
objects.html:
MADISON, Wis. —

A campus COVID-19 outbreak at University of Wisconsin-Madison is threatening the semester, a semester that's not even a week old.

The school added 21 new student cases Tuesday, but only 93 students were tested because of the holiday.

Since Aug. 6, 1,004 people have tested positive on campus. Mass testing is revealing how widespread the virus is there.

The number of new COVID-19 cases has been rising every day for nearly a week. Now, with fraternities and sororities ordered to test everyone, that number is expected rise even more.

It's a strange time to be in college with the coronavirus spreading more rapidly, threatening to close campus.

"I think that's a very strong possibility in the coming weeks here. I think we're almost expecting it, so, I mean, just to see if they actually do and depending on -- I don't think it's an if but a when," UW-Madison freshman Nelson Summary said.

UW-Chancellor Rebecca Blank is restricting students to essential activities: food, classes and jobs. Masks are now required even outside.

"We've reached the point where we need to quickly flatten the curve of infection, or we will lose the opportunity to keep campus open to students this semester," Blank said.

"I definitely thinks it's necessary. From what I've seen from friends and peers in general, a lot of them aren't being as considerate and as responsible as we could be, so I definitely think her message was necessary," UW-Madison sophomore Georgia Maskalunas said.

The university said the issue appears to be campus parties and social gatherings. It confirmed they're investigating a video posted by Badger Barstool on Instagram showing a party in a COVID isolation dorm.

"A lot of our students are doing the right thing. And as always, it's just the behavior of a few that are potentially putting all of the rest of us at risk," said Lori Reesor, vice chancellor for student affairs.

"There are restrictions applied, so we are trying to keep those into consideration because we don't want to get sent home. Our goal is just to stay here as long as possible," UW-Madison freshman Thomas Hatton said,

For now, in-person classes and labs will be allowed to continue. The chancellor said there's no evidence of the virus spreading in classes.

Beyond the mandatory testing for students in residence halls, fraternities and sororities, all students can get a free test on their own, even if they don't have symptoms.

UW-Madison: Undergraduates must limit in-person interaction

The school added 21 new student cases Tuesday, but only 93 students were tested because of the holiday.
Since Aug. 6, 1,004 people have tested positive on campus. Mass testing is revealing how widespread the virus is there.
The number of new COVID-19 cases has been rising every day for nearly a week. Now, with fraternities and sororities ordered to test everyone, that number is expected rise even more.
It's a strange time to be in college with the coronavirus spreading more rapidly, threatening to close campus.
"I think that's a very strong possibility in the coming weeks here. I think we're almost expecting it, so, I mean, just to see if they actually do and depending on -- I don't think it's an if but a when," UW-Madison freshman Nelson Summary said.
UW-Chancellor Rebecca Blank is restricting students to essential activities: food, classes and jobs. Masks are now required even outside.
"We've reached the point where we need to quickly flatten the curve of infection, or we will lose the opportunity to keep campus open to students this semester," Blank said.
"I definitely thinks it's necessary. From what I've seen from friends and peers in general, a lot of them aren't being as considerate and as responsible as we could be, so I definitely think her message was necessary," UW-Madison sophomore Georgia Maskalunas said.
The university said the issue appears to be campus parties and social gatherings. It confirmed they're investigating a video posted by Badger Barstool on Instagram showing a party in a COVID isolation dorm.
"A lot of our students are doing the right thing. And as always, it's just the behavior of a few that are potentially putting all of the rest of us at risk," said Lori Reesor, vice chancellor for student affairs.
"There are restrictions applied, so we are trying to keep those into consideration because we don't want to get sent home. Our goal is just to stay here as long as possible," UW-Madison freshman Thomas Hatton said,
For now, in-person classes and labs will be allowed to continue. The chancellor said there's no evidence of the virus spreading in classes.
Beyond the mandatory testing for students in residence halls, fraternities and sororities, all students can get a free test on their own, even if they don't have symptoms.
